trial_identification.studytitle: The effect of massage and joint mobilisation in the management of long term breathing problems
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of including spinal manipulation in the management of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease within a standardised pulmonary rehabilitation program

interventions.interventions: Intervention: massage (15 minutes), spinal manipulation (5 minutes) at 2 x week for 8 weeks
interventions.comparator: Comparator: pulmonary rehabilitation exercise program (treadmill walking, fixed cycling, free and fixed weight training, simple floor exercises) at 2 x week for 16 weeks

primaryOutcome.outcome: Forced Vital Capacity (FVC) and Forced Expiratory Volume in 1st second (FEV-1)

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At initial assessment and end of trial (16 weeks).
At initial assessment and end of trial (16 weeks).

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Referral to the Sutherland heart & lung health team (SHALT) pulmonary rehabilitation exercise program at Sutherland Hospital; non-smoking for 12 months.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Non-ambulatory; bone density readings of a T score <-2.5 and/or a Z score < -1; the presence of any contra-indication to spinal manipulation of the thoracic spine and/or posterior rib articulations.

trial_design.concealment: Allocation to intervention groups was concealed by using sealed opaque envelopes.
trial_design.sequence: Group allocation was done by simple randomisation using coin-tossing.

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: Peter Gonski - SOUTHCARE Sutherland Hospital, Sydney. Australia

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The rib cage, spine and muscles of the chest wall play an important role in breathing. Pulmonary rehabilitation exercise programs have been shown to improve pulmonary function and quality of life in people suffering from emphysema and/or chronic bronchitis. This trial tests a new treatment aimed at improving the outcomes of an existing pulmonary rehabilitation exercise program. Massage and joint mobilisation will be applied to the joints and muscles of the chest wall in people undertaking a standardised pulmonary rehabilitation exercise program in an attempt to increase the improvement in lung function normally associated with such programs.
